summary: The Virgin Islands Department of Justice submits a Touhy request to the SMART Office seeking all records of Jeffrey Epstein's international travel from June 2008 to August 2019, as required under sex offender registration laws. The request is part of the GVI's civil case against Epstein's estate for violations of human trafficking and abuse laws in the Virgin Islands.

keyFacts: The Government of the Virgin Islands is pursuing a civil case (ST-2020-CV-14) against Epstein's estate under the Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO) for human trafficking, child abuse, and sexual abuse violations.
As a registered sex offender since June 2008, Epstein was required under SORNA to notify the SMART Office at least 21 days in advance of any international travel.

The Virgin Islands DOJ is specifically requesting all records of Epstein's international travel from June 2008 to August 2019 from SMART and associated agencies like the U.S. Marshals Service, INTERPOL-Washington, FBI, and DHS Angel Watch Center.
The request is framed as essential for the prosecution of the case, indicating the travel records are believed to contain evidence relevant to the alleged crimes in the Virgin Islands.
